title: How your eyes predict your personality
intro: Watch where you're watching! Apparently, where your eyes look can be used to predict things about your personality. Could this be the personality test of the future? Neil and Rob discuss how your eyes predict your personality and teach you related vocabulary.
this_week_question: The letters 'AI' stand for Artificial Intelligence but what are the letters 'AI'? Are they
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: someone who has a very outgoing personality, confident and socially comfortable.
someone who is shy and not comfortable in social situations and doesn’t like being the centre of attention.
the results and conclusions of research
the way that someone looks at someone

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I'm Rob.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, Rob, would you say that you are an introvert or an extrovert?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: What a good question! Well, extroverts are confident in their personality. They're outgoing and comfortable in social situations. So, I would have to say that, if anything, I’m the opposite. I’m more of an introvert . I’m really quite shy. I feel uncomfortable in social situations. For example, if I go to a party, where I don’t know anyone I usually feel very embarrassed and I find it impossible to start conversations with strangers.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But you do all of this on the radio and videos for Learning English, don’t you? Some would say you have to be an extrovert to do what we do.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Ah! Well, maybe I’m pretending to be an extrovert to hide the fact that I’m an introvert . It’s quite a common thing, you know.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, it might not be so easy to hide in the future because researchers have developed a computer program that can tell your personality from looking at where you look, by tracking your eye movements.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Wow! That sounds pretty hi-tech, and scary.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, we’ll learn more shortly, but first a question on the topic of clever computers. The letters 'AI' stand for Artificial Intelligence but what are the letters 'AI'? Are they

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, I thought that was going to be easy, but I think it’s an abbreviation, isn’t it?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, you’ll have to wait to the end of the programme to find out! Sabrina Hoppe is a researcher at the University of Stuttgart. She was interviewed on the BBC Radio programme All In The Mind. She spoke about an experiment in which they tracked the eye movements of people in real situations. This is what she said about the research. Was she confident the experiment would work in the real world?

transcript.author: Sabrina Hoppe
transcript.text: The main finding in our study is that it is possible at all to just look at eye movements and then predict something about their personality. And before our study, it was not clear at all if this would be possible from eye movements in such an unconstrained real world setting.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, was she confident this would work?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: No, not really. She said that before the study it wasn’t clear if it would be possible in an unconstrained real-world setting. Unconstrained here means that there wasn’t strict control over the conditions of the experiment. It took place in the ‘real-world’ – so not in a laboratory.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The result of the experiment - or the finding , as she called it - was that by following eye movements, a computer programme was able to work out the personality of the subjects. Let’s listen again.

transcript.author: Sabrina Hoppe
transcript.text: The main finding in our study is that it is possible at all to just look at eye movements and then predict something about their personality. And before our study, it was not clear at all if this would be possible from eye movements in such an unconstrained real world setting.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So how does the software work, for example, what are the differences in the eye movements of extroverts compared to introverts ?

transcript.author: Sabrina Hoppe
transcript.text: We still don't really know in detail what makes the difference. We can only tell that there are differences and that we know computer programs that can pick up those differences. Maybe extrovert people look up a lot because they want to look at people's faces, whereas some super introvert person maybe just stares at their own shoes, if you want to take the extreme examples. So, probably it somehow changes gaze. But we only know that this information is there and somehow our program figured out how to extract it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So how does it work?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, that’s the strange thing. She said that she didn’t really know, at least not in detail. She did say that our personality somehow changes gaze . Gaze is another word for looking at something. So maybe we gaze in different ways depending on our personality. Extroverts may look up more and introverts, like me, may look down more.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, it was interesting that she said that she didn’t know how it did it, but the program somehow managed to figure it out . The phrasal verb to figure something out means 'to understand or realise something'.  Time to review today’s vocabulary, but first, let’s have the answer to the quiz question. I asked what are the letters AI? Are they

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I said A) an abbreviation.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well sorry, no, AI is C), so to speak. It's an initialism. It’s the first letters of the words 'artificial intelligence', but it’s not pronounced like a new word, just the initial letters. Right, time now to review today’s vocabulary.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes. We had the word extrovert . This describes someone who has a very outgoing personality. An extrovert is confident and socially comfortable.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: By contrast, an introvert is someone who is shy and not comfortable in social situations and doesn’t like being the centre of attention.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Our report today talked about the findings of some new research. A finding is something that has been learnt, discovered or indeed, found out. It is the conclusion that is reached.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Then we had unconstrained to describe the experiment which was not carried out in a controlled environment. So unconstrained means 'not limited or restricted'.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Our next word was gaze . This is a word that means 'our way of looking at something'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, the findings of the research suggest that our personality can affect our gaze .

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And this was something the computer was able to figure out . To figure out means 'to study something and reach an answer to a particular question or problem'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right! Well, you know what I’ve just figured out ?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Do tell!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It’s time to bring this edition of 6 Minute English to an end. We hope you can join us again, but until then we are bbclearningenglish.com and you can find us on social media, online and on our app. Bye for now.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Bye-bye!
